articles.author: Jo√£o Victor
articles.description:
Reward : $2500



  
  
  Overview of the Vulnerability


A backup copy of the Global.asa file was found publicly accessible on the web server. This file is commonly used in classic ASP applications and may contain sensitive information, such as database connection strings, file paths, application-level settings, or authentication logic. If exposed, it can assist an attacker in gaining deeper access to the application or underlying infrastructure.
During a fuzzing process using the wordlist available at:
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/onvio/wordlists/master/words_and_files_top5000.txt
we discovered the following publicly accessible backup file:
https://cangacei[.]ro/Global.asa.bak
This file was successfully downloaded and, upon inspection, it was found to contain plaintext credentials along with instructions pointing to another directory within the application. By following this path, we were able to access additional sensitive information, including:
This exposure represents a significant security risk, as it provides direct access to internal application logic, user data, and potentially database systems.
articles.title: Global.asa backup file found

articles.author: Amanda
articles.description:
We‚Äôve all been there: vague API docs, an outdated OpenAPI spec, and a half-buried list of endpoints that leave you guessing. With prebuilt REST Connectors, you skip the guesswork. Just download the schema files, run your graph locally, and start querying live data with GraphQL.
In this guide, we‚Äôll use the Space Devs Launch Library 2 in the Connectors Community repo as an example to show how easy it is to integrate a REST API into your graph in minutes and how you can tailor it to meet your needs.
-Create an Apollo Studio account. This allows you to create and manage your graph, providing the necessary credentials, APOLLO_KEY and APOLLO_GRAPH_REF (more on those later‚Ä¶) which the Apollo Router uses to fetch the supergraph schema and run locally.
Install and authenticate Rover CLI which we w‚Ä¶
articles.title: From REST to GraphQL in minutes with prebuilt Connectors

articles.author: Peyman
articles.description:
By Peyman Hassan
There‚Äôs a strange and beautiful tension in the world we‚Äôve created‚Äîa space where artificial intelligence hums quietly in the background of our daily lives, curating, optimizing, anticipating. It's a world designed for ease. A world where, before the sunlight even warms your windowpane, an algorithm already knows how you slept, recommends your breakfast, and lines up your day like dominoes.
And yet, as I sip my morning coffee, I find myself wondering:
This is the fracture‚Äîthe subtle crack between the life we live and the life we are nudged into living. A fracture not just between human and machine, but between convenience and consciousness, control and surrender, existence and intention.
We created AI to help us understand the world. But as it grows more intelligent, more c‚Ä¶
articles.title: AI Fracture and Life: Walking the Edge Between Code and Consciousness

articles.author: Chris Jarvis
articles.description:
This is a submission for Frontend Challenge - June Celebrations, Perfect Landing: June Celebrations
How is a web site like a Dad joke? It needs a good landing.
Father's Day means you have to laugh at your Dad's joke. For this challenge, I built a landing page for dad jokes. It has plenty of Dad jokes, a button to get a random joke, and links to more dad jokes related content.
This is the codepen for the site.




The live page. 
live page
I was trying to figure something do for a June Celebration. Fathers Day's was just a few days away. Humor and jokes are a big part of my family so I focused on laughing with my dad and son.
This is a static HTML site with a button that calls a Joke API. I modified my code from a Danny Thompson tutorial from a while ago. I could have changed APIs but this one had a filter option to block inappropriate jokes. I set the call to send puns and block NSFW stuff.
The color pallet is based off of Dad's Root Beer branding. I thought about making a CSS version of the can for the art challenge but wanted something up the Friday before Father's Day. I may do it before DEV's Challenge Deadline of June 29.
The cover image was made with Photoshop. The logo is what was envisioned for the CSS Art. It might be added to the live page.

I visited a bunch of joke sites to find some that were decent to share. I'd like to add a section to submit your own jokes. This is not finished, It will be updates as time allows. Just wanted it up before Father's Day.
This was a fun early internet kind of build. I really enjoyed researching and building it.
articles.title: Father's Day means Dad Jokes.

articles.author: ronak wanjari
articles.description:
By Ronak Wanjari | Intern at @devsyncin 
Functions are the heart of JavaScript, and understanding how they work internally helps write better and cleaner code. As I learned during my internship at @devsyncin , every function in JavaScript creates its own world called the Execution Context when it runs.
üß† What's Inside a Function Execution?
When a function is invoked, JavaScript creates:
üì¶ A Variable Environment ‚Äì stores variables and parameters.
üîó A Scope Chain ‚Äì connects it to outer environments.
üßç‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è A this keyword ‚Äì depends on how the function is called.
üìå** Understanding Variable Environment**
The Variable Environment includes:
Function parameters
Variables (var, let, const)
Inner function declarations
This environment is temporary and recreated every time the function is called.
function greet(name) {
  let message = "Hello " + name;
  return message;
}
Each call to greet("Ronak") creates a fresh environment with name = "Ronak" and message = "Hello Ronak".

üß© Hoisting & Variable Environment
function test() {
  console.log(x); // undefined
  var x = 5;
}
x exists in the environment but is undefined at first.


Mentored and guided by @devsyncin 


  
  
  JavaScript #Functions #VariableEnvironment #Hoisting #WebDevelopment #Devsync
articles.title: üîç How Functions Work in JavaScript ‚ù§Ô∏è & Variable Environment
